body: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. JOHN KATSIMATIDES Everything in Technicolor Cool New Yorkers drape themselves in black. Guess someone forgot to tell John Katsimatides. Because he was very cool and lived utterly in Technicolor. His Jet Ski and his Jeep were bright yellow. His Harley was baby
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE VICTIMS; A Vibrant Style, a Fountain of Fun and a Childhood Amid Cotton Fields

author: Herb McCormick is the editor of Cruising World magazine.
body: With a dramatic come-from-behind victory last Tuesday on Leg 2 of the Volvo Ocean Race from Cape Town to Sydney, Australia, the Illbruck Challenge from Germany is making the prognosticators look like seers. As many predicted, and as proven by its second consecutive individual leg triumph, Illbruck is the boat to beat. The most impressive part of
title: BOATING REPORT: NOTEBOOK; Despite Flooding, Illbruck Comes Back

body: In a game full of momentum swings, Sheepshead Bay used a big play on offense and took advantage of two Lehman fumbles to win its first Public Schools Athletic League championship, 26-16, yesterday at Midwood Field in Brooklyn. The Sharks finished the season with a 12-0 record. Glenroy Watkins, a linebacker and fullback, has been a force for the
title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL; Sheepshead Defeats Lehman For Title

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; A Surfing Firefighter, a Thrill-Riding Hunter, a Mormon Composer

body: The owner of a used-car lot in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday on charges that he smuggled or tried to smuggle 20 stolen luxury cars to Russia and Latvia, the United States Customs Service said. The man, Grigori Baranik, owner of Galaxy Auto Sales at 2733 Coney Island Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, bought some of the cars from owners who then reported
title: Dealer Charged In Car Smuggling

body: NO game this weekend because, officially, the season is over, though Pudgie Walsh has had the inescapable feeling of it being one game and a grand gesture short. His Brooklyn Mariners went 10-0 in the Garden State Football League of the semipro variety, but to put away the playbook he typically forsakes for his famed wild hunches would be akin to

body: It was a case of too little, too late. Despite a fourth-quarter rally, Freeport ended up a yard short and Farmingdale ended the Red Devils' 20-game winning streak with a 13-6 victory in the Nassau County Conference I title game yesterday at Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y. title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL; Freeport's 20-Game Streak Is Ended by Farmingdale

body: A sports article last Saturday about the Sheepshead Bay High School football team, in Brooklyn, reversed the references to two linebackers who also play on offense. Glenroy Watkins is a fullback on offense and entered the game against Campus Magnet with 620 yards and 5 touchdowns. Ed Lindsay plays tight end on offense.
title: Corrections

body: Two men were killed when the cars they were riding in collided on a Brighton Beach street, the police said yesterday. The driver of one car, Mark Ferdman, 29, of Sheepshead Bay, has been charged with driving while intoxicated and vehicular manslaughter, the police said. One of Mr. Ferdman's two passengers was his brother, Oleg Ferdman, 30, who was
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 2 Die In Crash

body: On a crisp October morning in the Bronx, the dean of students at Community School 61 walked into Clifton Moore's seventh-grade class and made an announcement. Three people in the class had been selected for applications to a program that sends underprivileged students to top private schools. A hush fell over the 26 students in the class as they
title: The Neediest Cases; For Many, Sliding Into Poverty Takes Only a Few Missed Paychecks

body: Last season Sheepshead Bay was just happy to have made it as far as the Public Schools Athletic League semifinals. But this year, the Sharks, with a regular-season record of 8-0, expect to contend for the league championship. title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL; Sheepshead Bay Seeks Date in Final

body: ''Every funeral is bigger than the last,'' the gray-haired woman in the black jacket said to her neighbor on the packed sidewalk across the street from St. Francis de Sales Roman Catholic Church. title: An Even Closer-Knit Belle Harbor Mourns Anew

body: A boy dribbled a basketball past imagined defenders. A woman took her dust mop of a dog for a walk. A white sanitation truck inched along, grinding the garbage in its hold. title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 587: BELLE HARBOR; 5 Neighbors Gone, and a Jet Engine Where a Child's Bike Might Have Been

title: PUBLIC LIVES; Stage Manager-Slash-Director Finds Christmas

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL; Farmingdale Gets It Done in 2nd Half

body: As a youth in Kazakhstan, Alexandr Manin had no interest in the war that the Soviet Union was waging in Afghanistan in the 1980's. But since arriving in New York three years ago, he has had a change of heart, and has joined the military. The United States military, that is. Mr. Manin, who is here as a legal permanent resident but is not yet a
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE RECRUITS; Not Yet Citizens but Eager to Fight for the U.S.

body: Virgil Avery scored three touchdowns yesterday to lead Brooklyn Tech (5-1) to a 27-7 victory over New Utrecht (3-3) at Wang Field in Brooklyn. Avery, a senior running back, leads the Public Schools Athletic League with 17 touchdowns on the season. ''He didn't even lead the team in yards,'' Coach Jim DiBenedetto said. ''He just finds the end zone.''
title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL; Avery's 3 Touchdowns Power Brooklyn Tech

body: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood at 393 yesterday, and the city medical examiner had identified 335. In all, 4,979 could be missing. title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; A Hunting Tradition Is Upheld, Along With a Bond Between Cousins

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Madison, Brooklyn; Spacious, Gracious and Close to School

body: ON Wednesday, Abraham Shirinzada, an Afghan coffee vendor, stood in the garage on 30th Street in Manhattan where he stores his cart and spoke about the concern his customers have shown after the attacks. title: REVERBERATIONS; Small Change, Big Acts of Kindness

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; Lives Remembered, by the Families and Friends Who Shared Them

body: WHEN Bill Parcells was coaching, he had a phrase for a rookie from the sticks. ''He's so country,'' Parcells liked to say, ''he has to go toward town to hunt.'' title: Sports of The Times; The Giants Were There Twice Before

body: Until Tuesday, few people beyond the rarefied world of the government bond market had ever heard of Cantor Fitzgerald L.P., a 57-year-old firm that is an important piece of the backstage machinery of the Treasury market. title: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE TRADING FIRM; An Emblem of Concern and Anxiety

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL; Poly Prep Stops Rally And Pulls Off an Upset

body: DIANA BELOZOVSKY was 13 when she and her parents set out on a complicated getaway from the Soviet Union. At the American Embassy in Rome, the girl's elementary-school English proved indispensable to her parents for the first time. ''This was very crucial,'' said Ms. Belozovsky, who is now 24. ''They were deciding whether we get to America or not.''
title: URBAN TACTICS; Translating for Parents Means Growing Up Fast

body: Asian-Americans, for years hardly a speck on the jigsaw puzzle of New York City's ethnic politics, are emerging this year as a force to be courted. Just look at the candidates running in the unusually crowded contest for mayor: they are popping into subway stations in Chinatown, taking tea with Indians in Staten Island, printing up Chinese-language
title: New Political Math in the City Raises Power of the Asian Vote

body: These days, when Claudine Barbot's telephone rings, she approaches with trepidation. She's never sure what she might hear. Some callers apologize for bothering her. Others do not. ''I'm an old lady,'' said Ms. Barbot, 70. ''I can't even repeat what they say. I am French. We don't speak like that.'' Ms. Barbot and many of her neighbors are victims
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SHEEPSHEAD BAY/MANHATTAN BEACH; Dial M for Muddle: A Cell-Phone Story That Never Ends

title: Talk Radio

body: WHEN police helicopters fly over his house in Sheepshead Bay, Robert Tanzer sometimes wakes up in a sweat, thinking he is back in Vietnam. He says the year he spent rescuing wounded men by helicopter in and around the Mekong Delta contained such painful scenes that he would rather not remember them. So why he does he spend three days a week at
title: CITY LORE; Props and Choppers of Old

title: A Motley Group, a Single Goal; Supporters Rally Round Officer Jailed in Louima Case

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK FOLKLORE; For Him, All Theater District Celebrities Are a Caricature

body: Officially, of course, it will always be the B train. But just take it on any given Sunday evening, along about half of its southerly course, and you might agree that it would not be much of an exaggeration to give the subway line a subtitle: the Fish Train. ''Whoa, man, it smells like fish in here,'' said Ramon Vasquez, a hotel maintenance worker.
title: Tunnel Vision; Bags of Joy, Pungent And Lucky

body: MARTY JOLTIN, who owns the Printing Store in the careworn part of Times Square, insists that he long ago tucked away his dreams of fame and fortune. title: COPING; Back When Hair and Harmonies Were Slick

body: With the palm of his hand, Michael S. Race pushed open the door of the Brooklyn courthouse, and there, standing under a spring sun and drawing their first breaths of freedom in 14 years, were Anthony Faison and Charles Shepherd: innocent men, home from serving time for someone else's murder. Mr. Race smiled. As a detective-sergeant during one of
title: Ex-Officer Off Tough Beat Seeks to Free the Innocent

body: Rockets Redglare, a comedian, actor and longtime fixture on the Lower East Side of Manhattan who played characters not unlike himself in many movies, died on May 28 in Manhattan. He was 52. The cause was complications of kidney failure, liver failure, cirrhosis and hepatitis C, said his cousin, Madeline Schuster. Rockets Redglare's rugged good
title: Rockets Redglare, 52, Film Actor and Comedian

body: They were born in exotic places, these two unheralded members of the Los Angeles Dodgers, places that are not the usual origin of major leaguers. Luke Prokopec, the Dodgers' surprisingly good rookie pitcher, was born in Blackwood, South Australia; Paul LoDuca, their good-hitting catcher-first baseman, was born in Brooklyn. title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK; A Part of Brooklyn Is With the Dodgers

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: City Worker Dies In Crash

body: It is not easy to explain why the partial shutdown of the Grand Street subway station has caused such outrage. After all, this is a city in which detours are a daily affair. Subway stations close for repairs all the time, and the Canal Street and Broadway station, the designated alternative to Grand Street, is not far. Grand Street will still be
title: Closing an Artery in Chinatown; Some Say Station Shutdown Threatens Brooklyn Ties

body: In the recent battle over plans to let a private company manage five low-performing schools, the loudest and most effective voice belonged to Acorn, the community group that led the opposition. But few people who followed that battle seemed aware that Acorn has itself been involved in the New York City school system for more than a decade, helping
title: Mixed School Record for Edison Foes

title: THEATER REVIEW; Still Brooklyn Wiseguys After All These Years

title: BASKETBALL: P.S.A.L.; Robeson and Grady Ease Their Way Into Boys' Final

body: RED HOOK isn't known for its concentration of grand houses, like Park Slope or Brooklyn Heights. Situated on a peninsula in western Brooklyn, cut off from the rest of the borough, its streets are filled mostly with workmanlike structures that don't demand a second look. That's why it's such a surprise to enter the simple brick house on Dikeman
title: Habitats/Red Hook, Brooklyn; Finding the Right House -- And Making It Livable

body: A 45-year-old man was struck and killed by a city bus last night as he tried to cross Coney Island Avenue in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, the authorities said. The man, whose name was not immediately released, was near the corner of Coney Island Avenue and Avenue X at 6 p.m. when a northbound B68 bus hit him, said Officer Cheryl Cox, a
title: Man Is Killed by Bus on a Brooklyn Street

author: Jill Eisenstadt, who was born in Brooklyn and lives there now, is the author of two novels, ''From Rockaway'' and ''Kiss Out.''
body: KICK the can. The seltzer man. Dem bums. The candy store. A charlotte russe made the right way, with a ring of cardboard around the sponge cake. Cafeterias and bowling alleys.
